A faster way for a computer to calculate which pixels to colour in to give the appearance of a straight line between two points is to use Brensenham's Line Algorithm. If you haven't done so you can read more about it on CS Field Guide.

Next

The algorithm uses three variables A, B and P. First of all we need to calculate the initial values of these variables using the following equations:

We can substitute the given coordinates into these equations.

Next

Once we have calculated the initial values of A, B and P we can start drawing the line following a few simple rules.

  • If P is less than 0, color in a new pixel on the same line as the last pixel, and add A to P.
  • If P is greater than or equal to 0, color in a new pixel in the line above the last pixel, and add B to P.

And repeat this decision until we reach the end point.

Next

P is greater than 0 so we pick the pixel that is one line above the previous one and add B to P.

P is equal to 0 so we pick the pixel that is one line above the previous one and add B to P.

P is less than 0 so we pick the pixel that is in line with the previous one and add A to P.

SkipNext

Once we get to the end point we have finished drawing the line. Would you like me to show you again?
